highlights.para: This chapter introduces you to the basic skills that you need to work with your desktop.

sect1.title: Mouse Skills
sect1.para: Even if you are very familiar with mouse devices, you should still familiarize yourself with the use of the mouse in the desktop.

sect2.title: Mouse Button Conventions
sect2.para:
All the instructions in this manual are for the following types of mouse devices:
Devices that are configured for right-hand users.
Three button devices. If you have a two-button mouse device, then you press the two buttons simultaneously to simulate the effect of a middle mouse button.
The mouse button conventions used in this manual are as follows:

entry.para: The button on the left side of a mouse device configured for normal right-hand use.
The middle button of a mouse device configured for normal right-hand use.
The button on the right side of a mouse device configured for normal right-hand use.

sect2.para: You can use the Mouse capplet in the Control Center to reverse the handedness of your mouse device. If you do reverse the handedness of your mouse device, then you must reverse the mouse button conventions used in this manual.

sect2.title: Mouse Actions
sect2.para: When you use your mouse with the desktop, the following UNIX mouse conventions apply.

entry.para:
Use to perform the following actions:
Select text.
Choose items.
Drag items.

Use to perform the following actions:
Paste text.
Move items.
Open a menu if a menu applies.
Opens a menu for the selected object, if a menu applies.

sect2.para: For example, if you want to copy text then perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Select the text with the left mouse button.
Move the mouse pointer to the location where you want to copy the text.
Click on the middle mouse button.

sect2.para: You can also use your mouse to open the following menus.

sect2.title: Mouse Action Terminology
sect2.para: The conventions used in this manual to describe actions that you take with the mouse are as follows:

entry.para: Press and release the left mouse button, without moving the mouse.
Press and do not release the left mouse button.
Same as click. Left-click clarifies the action when there might be confusion with right-click.
Press and release the middle mouse button, without moving the mouse.
Press and release the right mouse button, without moving the mouse.
Press and release the left mouse button twice in rapid succession without moving the mouse.
Click-and-hold a mouse button, then move an object. For example, you can drag a window or an icon. In the desktop, the left and middle mouse buttons can perform drag actions.
Click-and-hold a mouse button, then move an object. For example, you can drag-and-drop a window or an icon. Release the mouse button to place the object in a new location.
Point to an item that you can move, and click-and-hold on the mouse button. For example, you can grab the titlebar of a window, then drag the window to a new location.

sect2.title: Mouse Pointers
sect2.para: As you use the mouse, the appearance of the mouse pointer can change. The appearance of the pointer can provide feedback about a particular operation, location, or state. The following table lists and describes some of the mouse pointers in GNOME.

entry.para: Point to an item, choose a menu item
Normal pointer. The pointer that appears during normal use of the mouse.
Move pointer. Indicates that when you drop the object, the object is moved from the old location to the new location.
Copy pointer. Indicates that when you drop the object, a copy of the object is created where you drop the object.
Link pointer. Indicates that when you drop the object, a link to the object is created where you drop the object.
Ask pointer. Indicates that when you drop the object, a menu opens. You can choose to move or copy the object, or to create a link to the object.
Not available pointer. Indicates that you can not drop the object at the current location.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of move panel object pointer

entry.para: Move panel object pointer. Indicates that you have selected a panel object to move.
Horizontal resize pointer. Indicates that you have selected a vertical window border to resize the window horizontally.
Vertical resize pointer. Indicates that you have selected a horizontal window border to resize the window vertically.
Corner resize pointer. Indicates that you have selected a corner of a window border to resize the window horizontally and vertically.

textobject.phrase: Screenshot of window pane or table column resize pointer

entry.para: Resize window pane or table column
Window pane or table column resize pointer. Indicates that you have selected a column in a table to resize.

sect1.title: Using Shortcut Keys
sect1.para: A shortcut key is a series of one or more keystrokes or mouse clicks that provides a quick way to perform an action.

sect2.title: Application Shortcut Keys
sect2.para: Application shortcut keys enable you to perform an application-specific task from a shortcut key. The following table lists some application shortcut keys:
You can modify application shortcut keys. To modify an application shortcut key perform the following steps:

listitem.para: Open the application in which you want to modify the shortcut key.
Click once on the menu that contains the shortcut key that you want to modify.
Point to the menu item so that the menu item is highlighted.
Press the key or keys that you want to use as the shortcut key for the menu item. The new shortcut key is displayed in the menu.

sect1.title: Using Windows and Dialogs
sect1.para: This section provides information on how to use windows and dialogs in the GNOME desktop.

sect2.title: Navigating Windows and Dialogs
sect2.para: Most application windows contain a menubar. The menubar provides access to commands that you can use in the application. To choose an item in a menu, click on the menu, then click on the item that you want to choose. You can also use the keyboard to choose menu items. One letter in each menu is underlined. To open a menu, press the modifier key, then press the letter that is underlined. For example, in the gedit application, you can press ModifierF to open the File menu. One letter in each menu item is underlined. To choose a menu item, press the letter that is underlined. For example, to open a new file, press N.

You can also use the keyboard to access elements in a dialog. In a dialog, one letter in most dialog elements is underlined. To access a particular dialog element, press the modifier key, then press the letter that is underlined. For example, in the Preferences dialog in gedit, you can press ModifierW to give focus to the Tab width spin box.
You can also use the Tab key and the arrow keys to move from element to element in a dialog.

sect2.title: Resizing Panes in Windows
sect2.para: Some windows contain more than one pane. A pane is a subdivision of a window. For example, the Nautilus window contains a navigation pane and a view pane. Windows that contain panes have a resize handle on the edge between the panes. You can grab the resize handle and drag the edge to resize the pane.

sect2.title: Using Columns in Windows
sect2.para: Some windows contain information that is organized in a columned list. This section describes how to work with columns.
To change the width of a column, drag one of the vertical edges of the column.

In some columned lists, you can sort the information by a particular column. To sort information in a columned list, click on the heading above the column by which you want to sort the information. An up arrow is displayed in the column heading by which the list is sorted. The following figure shows the up arrow.
To reverse the sort order, click on the column heading again. The up arrow changes to a down arrow. The down arrow indicates that the information in the column is sorted in reverse order.
In some columned lists, you can select multiple items. The following table describes how to select items in columned lists.

entry.para: Select a group of contiguous items
Press and hold Shift. Click on the first item in the group, then click on the last item in the group.
Press and hold Ctrl. Click on the items that you want to select.
